quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What I'm feeling now is just an incredible sense of focus and urgency. Things have hit a tipping point where these models are now truly able to deliver for consumers.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical product/strategy signal: when tech hits a consumer-ready tipping point, teams should shift into focused, urgent execution.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The core Google search isn't really changing, in my opinion.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Contrarian stance that even amid AI disruption, the core user job-to-be-done can remain stable while the interface evolves.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: AI is expansionary. There's actually just more and more questions being asked and curiosity that can be fulfilled now with AI.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A mental model for market sizing: AI can grow total demand (more questions) rather than merely cannibalize existing search behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You need to be the physical manifestation of two pieces of things. One is just relentlessness, just complete effort that is always exerted in a direction of positive productivity. And then the second is make things better. You have to always make things better. You're never content.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concrete operating philosophy for teams: pair sustained execution intensity with continuous improvement and zero complacency.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Not every great thing is going to be invented by you.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Permission-giving guidance for product leaders to adopt proven patterns rather than over-index on originality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta helps companies of all sizes get compliant fast and stay that way with industry-leading AI automation and continuous monitoring.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable methodology—automation plus continuous monitoring—for maintaining compliance over time, not just achieving it once.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta also helps you complete security questionnaires up to five times faster so that you can win bigger deals sooner.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Connects a concrete operational improvement (faster questionnaires) to a direct business outcome (closing larger deals faster).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: According to a recent IDC study, Vanta customers slashed over $500,000 a year and are three times more productive.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Provides specific benchmark data practitioners can use to estimate ROI from compliance automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The hardest part of building products isn't actually building products, it's everything else.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Jira Product Discovery)
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that emphasizes discovery, alignment, and stakeholder management as the real bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Jira Product Discovery, you can capture insights and prioritize high-impact ideas.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Jira Product Discovery)
quotes.context: Summarizes a practical workflow—insight capture plus prioritization—that teams can adopt to focus on impact.

quotes.topic_title: Gemini hits #1: what changed at Google
quotes.text: I'm always shocked, even for things in search, people, we think they're very obvious. They sit right in the core search experience and then on X, I'll go look and like, "Oh, I just found out about this AI thing," and it seems very obvious, but I think a lot of people are just discovering quite how powerful these tools are.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Highlights a practical growth lever: even “obvious” features may need better discovery because users often don’t notice what’s right in front of them.

quotes.topic_title: Gemini hits #1: what changed at Google
quotes.text: what I'm feeling now is just an incredible sense of focus and urgency to deliver great products quickly.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concise operating principle teams can apply: prioritize focus and speed to ship product value faster.

quotes.topic_title: Gemini hits #1: what changed at Google
quotes.text: When you have that energy, and I think the product teams and the tech, the research groups are working really closely together, we're able to move and we're getting a lot done.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Points to an execution methodology: tighter research–product collaboration increases throughput and delivery pace.

quotes.topic_title: Gemini hits #1: what changed at Google
quotes.text: I don't think there's any one thing that has happened. I think that a lot of times people ascribe a lot of momentum to a one time change or a single person.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Challenges the common narrative of “one big bet” by emphasizing that momentum is rarely attributable to a single change or individual.

quotes.topic_title: Gemini hits #1: what changed at Google
quotes.text: I find a lot of this is actually this compounding effect when you think about just every month ruthlessly improving the product or the models and just every day getting better, and then it just hits this tipping point where people just like it, they use it more, they enjoy it.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Offers a repeatable mental model for product growth: compounding incremental improvements can create a tipping point in user adoption and satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Is search dying? AI as expansionary
quotes.text: I think the vastness of that is underappreciated by many people.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A reminder to model “search” (or any user need) as a huge, diverse surface area before declaring it disrupted.

quotes.topic_title: Is search dying? AI as expansionary
quotes.text: AI hasn't really changed those foundational needs in many ways, and what we're finding is that AI is expansionary, and so there's actually just more and more questions being asked and curiosity that can be fulfilled now with AI.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model: AI may grow total query volume by unlocking new curiosity rather than replacing core behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Is search dying? AI as expansionary
quotes.text: Google Lens, one of the fastest growing products out there, it's growing 70% year-over-year increase in visual searches, which is already at a massive scale.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concrete data point practitioners can use to justify investing in multimodal/visual query experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Is search dying? AI as expansionary
quotes.text: It's billions and billions and billions of searching in that way.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Highlights that “new” AI-enabled interaction modes can reach enormous scale, not just niche usage.

quotes.topic_title: Is search dying? AI as expansionary
quotes.text: And then just take a picture of your bookshelf and say, "What are the books I should get based on these books?"
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical example of how AI expands search into contextual, personalized recommendations from real-world inputs.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode explained: Overviews, multimodal, and integration
quotes.text: I can tell you there's three big components to how we can think about AI search and the next generation of search experiences.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A simple three-part framework practitioners can use to reason about modern AI search product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode explained: Overviews, multimodal, and integration
quotes.text: There's 50 billion products in the Google shopping graph, for instance. They're updated 2 billion times an hour by merchants with live prices. You have 250 million places in maps.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Concrete scale/data points illustrating how AI Mode leverages proprietary, frequently-updated knowledge graphs beyond the open web.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode explained: Overviews, multimodal, and integration
quotes.text: You should be able to not have to think about where you're asking a question ultimately, you just go to Google.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A product principle for integrating multiple AI entry points into a single, seamless user mental model.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode explained: Overviews, multimodal, and integration
quotes.text: So you can just ask really hard, you could put a five sentence question right into Google search.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical usage shift (long, complex queries) that signals how AI changes what “good” search input looks like.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode explained: Overviews, multimodal, and integration
quotes.text: It should feel like a consistent simple product experience ultimately, but obviously this is a new thing for us, and so we wanted to start it in a way that people could use and give us feedback with something like a direct entry point like google.com/ai.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A rollout methodology: launch a separate entry point to gather feedback, then progressively integrate into the core product.

quotes.topic_title: Natural language search and the Ask Jeeves loop
quotes.text: this idea that startups is a game of getting distribution before incumbents can innovate fast enough.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A crisp competitive framework for how startups can win by scaling distribution ahead of incumbent product catch-up.

quotes.topic_title: Natural language search and the Ask Jeeves loop
quotes.text: What we found is that people are asking these questions in Google. They're trying to get this out of Google.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A product discovery insight: user behavior is already pulling Google toward AI-style Q&A, signaling real demand.

quotes.topic_title: Natural language search and the Ask Jeeves loop
quotes.text: They type in keywords, we call it sometimes keyword ease, but you can actually use natural language in Google. That's the biggest shift.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Highlights a behavioral shift practitioners can design for: moving from keyword optimization to natural-language intent capture.

quotes.topic_title: Natural language search and the Ask Jeeves loop
quotes.text: We're seeing people asking real long, hard, complex questions.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concrete signal of changing query patterns that affects search UX, content strategy, and how answers should be structured.

quotes.topic_title: Natural language search and the Ask Jeeves loop
quotes.text: Yeah, Ask Jeeves was surprisingly prescient on that, huh? They had material, they had something way before its time that we think looks to rally around now.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that the “natural language question” paradigm is a revival of an older model, now enabled by better AI.

quotes.topic_title: AEO/GEO and how AI answers are constructed
quotes.text: when our AI constructs a response, it's actually trying to, it does something called query fan-out where the model uses Google search as a tool to find to do other querying.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Explains the core mechanism behind AI answers—multiple background searches—so creators can optimize for being retrieved across many related queries.

quotes.topic_title: AEO/GEO and how AI answers are constructed
quotes.text: Maybe you're asking about specific shoes, it'll add up and append all of these other queries like maybe dozens of queries and start searching basically in the background.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of how one question expands into many sub-queries, implying content should cover adjacent intents and details.

quotes.topic_title: AEO/GEO and how AI answers are constructed
quotes.text: do you satisfy the user intent, what they're trying to get? Do you have sources? Do you cite your information? Is it original or is it repeating things that have been repeated 500 times?
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical checklist for content that’s more likely to be selected when AI systems “do research and find information.”

quotes.topic_title: AEO/GEO and how AI answers are constructed
quotes.text: I think the only thing I would give advice to would be think about what people are using AI for.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Shifts optimization from traditional SEO tactics to demand-driven content strategy based on AI-era user behavior.

quotes.topic_title: AEO/GEO and how AI answers are constructed
quotes.text: one of the things that makes it unique for designing it specifically for informational tasks, we wanted to be the best at informational needs, that's what's Google's all about, and so how does it find information? How does it know if information is right? How does it check its work?
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A memorable product-building mental model: design AI around verification loops (finding, validating, checking) for information-heavy use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Building AI products: language as the new interface
quotes.text: I think the most recent one, and this is true, something even within the last week or two, is that it's so obvious how human-like the interface is becoming with how you can communicate and steer AI.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Highlights a key product shift: treating natural language as the primary UI for controlling AI behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Building AI products: language as the new interface
quotes.text: I think it used to be even just months back that you had to do a lot of work to get the AI to do the thing you're trying to get it to do, right? You had to do these incantations, you had to prompt in a really specific way.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A counterpoint to “prompt engineering” as a durable skill—suggesting the need for hacks is rapidly diminishing.

quotes.topic_title: Building AI products: language as the new interface
quotes.text: But increasingly, you can just use language.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concise, actionable takeaway: invest in clearer instructions and specs rather than complex training pipelines.

quotes.topic_title: Building AI products: language as the new interface
quotes.text: So I think it's going to open up a lot of this democratization of accessing these models and building incredible things because you don't even need to do a lot. To get the most sophisticated outcomes increasingly, I don't think you need to do a lot of this heavy duty fine-tuning.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A strategic product-development implication: sophisticated results may come from instruction + tool-use, not heavy fine-tuning.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless improvement: dissatisfaction as a product superpower
quotes.text: One is just relentlessness, just complete effort, but is always exerted in a direction of positive productivity. And then the second is make things better. You have to always make things better, you're never content.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A simple two-part operating model for product builders: sustained effort + continuous quality improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless improvement: dissatisfaction as a product superpower
quotes.text: It's not that you're just unhappy. It's like you want the world to be better. You're driven out of a deep desire. It's that you feel this sense of dissatisfaction with what the world gives you. You want to make it better, and you're pushed and motivated to do that.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Reframes “dissatisfaction” as a constructive product superpower rather than a negative personality trait.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless improvement: dissatisfaction as a product superpower
quotes.text: But for the things that went well, there was always this spirit of just we're going to get it eventually if we just make two more moves to make it better.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: keep iterating with small, concrete improvements past the point where others would stop.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless improvement: dissatisfaction as a product superpower
quotes.text: And then eventually, as I talked about before earlier in our conversation, you get this tipping point where it just tips over into being net useful to people because of just that amount of compounding effort that you put into something because you're just always so... You're the harshest critic and the most dissatisfied person in the room about your own work basically.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A compounding-improvement mental model: relentless iteration can push a product over a usefulness threshold.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless improvement: dissatisfaction as a product superpower
quotes.text: We habituate to everything. We accept and we tolerate what the world gives us everywhere, and we just go, "Oh, that kind of sucks. Oh, well," we shrug our shoulders and we move on.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode—normalizing friction—that great product thinkers actively resist.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode origin story: users appending 'AI' to queries
quotes.text: It's like we actually saw people in the query stream putting the words AI at the end of their queries because they're trying to get the AI to do the thing.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concrete example of using real user behavior as a signal for unmet product needs.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode origin story: users appending 'AI' to queries
quotes.text: We would look at that and be like, "This is ridiculous. We need to build something here."
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic: when users resort to hacks, treat it as a product gap worth building for.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode origin story: users appending 'AI' to queries
quotes.text: And that was one of the big motivations, was actually identifying that user problem, being very disgruntled on behalf of the user.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practitioner mindset: channel user frustration into urgency and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: AI Mode origin story: users appending 'AI' to queries
quotes.text: Instead of saying, "Oh, we don't need to solve for that," or, "That's not something that's in the most addressable next thing."
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A counterpoint to incrementalism—don’t dismiss hard problems just because they don’t fit the next obvious roadmap slice.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing craft and metrics: instrumentation as a guide
quotes.text: Yeah, I don't think of them as an or. I think they have to be intersected because basically the way I think about it is you actually start with a problem or the inverse of that, which is a vision, but they're connected.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Reframes the common craft-vs-KPIs debate into an intersection: start from problem/vision, then validate with metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing craft and metrics: instrumentation as a guide
quotes.text: So it comes out of this dissatisfaction and this sense of better that you need to make things better, but then you're going to build, and at the end of the day, you need your instrumentation to know if you're on the right track.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: pair product taste with instrumentation so you can verify whether “better” is actually working.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing craft and metrics: instrumentation as a guide
quotes.text: You might look at something like a J-curve. This is the retention, the percentage of people still using the product day seven, day 30, day 90, and does it flatten or do people just drip out of there?
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Concrete methodology for diagnosing product-market fit using retention curves across time horizons.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing craft and metrics: instrumentation as a guide
quotes.text: If your product, let's say, let's say our core metrics down 5% this week, it's like, well, what's going on? And so you be really close to root cause analysis there and say, "Well, actually it turns out that it's an issue. Is it in a region? Is it on a device? Is it in a demographic? Is it in a use case? Where does my problem lie?"
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical root-cause checklist for metric drops that helps teams localize issues quickly and systematically.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing craft and metrics: instrumentation as a guide
quotes.text: I'm a pilot to know if this thing is going and flying correctly, but then it doesn't tell you exactly what to do, you have to thank for yourself how to make it better.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Memorable mental model: metrics are instruments for direction, but judgment still determines the interventions.

quotes.topic_title: Instagram Stories: copying a format and making it yours
quotes.text: you have to really understand why someone uses your product and know when something is actually an existential question because there's just a better format or a different way of doing something that has worked and works and you need to figure out what that might mean for you, because not every great thing is going to be invented by you.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A decision-making lens for when to adopt an external innovation: treat proven new formats as potentially existential and respond accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Instagram Stories: copying a format and making it yours
quotes.text: But I think that a lot of these things are, they can become formats that you can make your own and you need to learn from the world and what's happening out there in order for your product to always give the best thing to its users.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented philosophy: borrow formats, then differentiate through product-specific execution to best serve users.

quotes.topic_title: Instagram Stories: copying a format and making it yours
quotes.text: And whenever you try to mix a core product that's very cemented in someone's mind and physically looks a specific way and you're trying to make, contort it to do something new, it's usually a bad recipe.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product design warning: forcing new behavior into an established UI/mental model often fails versus creating a new surface.

quotes.topic_title: Instagram Stories: copying a format and making it yours
quotes.text: And so we made a bunch of decisions like that where why don't you just let people upload their photo? This is back to the dissatisfied point, that's frustrating.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concrete example of differentiation-by-removing-friction: use user dissatisfaction with incumbents to pick winning feature choices.

quotes.topic_title: Instagram Stories: copying a format and making it yours
quotes.text: So we added this pause, it's such a small thing, but you put your finger down to pause the story now.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A specific micro-interaction that illustrates how small UX decisions can meaningfully improve consumption and make a copied format feel native.

quotes.topic_title: Handling backlash: user-first rationale for 'borrowed' ideas
quotes.text: I mean, I think it's more that we're focused on our users and the people who are loving Instagram and it's denying them the opportunity to have an easy way to just share a photo and have the thing go away.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Reframes “copying” as removing user friction and expanding what existing users can do in the product.

quotes.topic_title: Handling backlash: user-first rationale for 'borrowed' ideas
quotes.text: At the end of the day, that is a format that people adopt.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A simple heuristic: if users broadly adopt a format, it can be legitimate to implement it when it fits your product’s needs.

quotes.topic_title: Handling backlash: user-first rationale for 'borrowed' ideas
quotes.text: Facebook probably created the modern feed, but there's a feed for every single product. There's a LinkedIn feed and there's a feed for DoorDash.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Illustrates the “core primitives” idea: successful interaction patterns propagate across categories and become table stakes.

quotes.topic_title: Handling backlash: user-first rationale for 'borrowed' ideas
quotes.text: These things become core primitives quickly and formats, and then at the end of the day, you're just robbing your user base of the opportunity to have a better product if you're not making the best possible product for your use cases.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Argues that refusing to adopt proven primitives can harm users when those primitives improve the product for your specific use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Handling backlash: user-first rationale for 'borrowed' ideas
quotes.text: And for Instagram, it's used differently. People use Instagram differently than they use other products.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: Emphasizes adapting shared formats to distinct usage patterns rather than copying implementations wholesale.

quotes.topic_title: Driving growth in mature products: jobs-to-be-done and new primitives
quotes.text: I view product like golf, you're always one stroke away from shanking. And as soon as you think you're good, you're not, you don't know anything. The world changes quickly. You have to always be a servant to your user base and the people that are out there and learn from them.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A memorable humility/learning mindset for operating mature products where complacency is the biggest risk.

quotes.topic_title: Driving growth in mature products: jobs-to-be-done and new primitives
quotes.text: First thing you do is you get a sense of what do people want out of this product? What's its true essence? I think a lot about this job to be done framework, which is one of the things that I'm a big fan of and Clayton Christensen's book on Competing Against Luck is one of my favorite books on this topic where you have to really be a student of causation. Why is someone using this product? What are they doing with it and what are they trying to get done with it?
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A concrete framework (jobs-to-be-done) for diagnosing growth opportunities by understanding causation, not features.

quotes.topic_title: Driving growth in mature products: jobs-to-be-done and new primitives
quotes.text: And that usually leads you to do bigger next stage ideas, and it removes this belief that you need to solve the problem with the current tools.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A counterintuitive push to escape incrementalism by not constraining solutions to existing product primitives.

quotes.topic_title: Driving growth in mature products: jobs-to-be-done and new primitives
quotes.text: And by adding them, it becomes complementary, not replacement.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A simple principle for introducing new formats into mature products without triggering user backlash.

quotes.topic_title: Driving growth in mature products: jobs-to-be-done and new primitives
quotes.text: The best way I've seen is by making it complimentary, having it be a core part of the experience, but clearly defined as a distinctive thing that has its own attributes associated with it because people think spatially.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical design heuristic: integrate new experiences as distinct primitives to match users’ mental models.

quotes.topic_title: Resource allocation: diminishing returns and new growth engines
quotes.text: That's one where I actually do feel like the more analytical, systematic thinking helps a lot because you're trying to produce value in the world, you want to quantify it some way.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: use analytical, quantifiable thinking to guide resource allocation decisions rather than intuition alone.

quotes.topic_title: Resource allocation: diminishing returns and new growth engines
quotes.text: You get to these points of just diminishing marginal return in every system where it feels like you could put 50 people on this project, it's just not going to dramatically move the needle.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A memorable signal for when optimization has peaked and additional headcount won’t meaningfully increase impact.

quotes.topic_title: Resource allocation: diminishing returns and new growth engines
quotes.text: Part of it is this bottoms up thing with your own team being really thoughtful about what is the expected value of that investment, and knowing when it's starting to approach zero or diminishing marginal return.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: An actionable method: evaluate expected value at the team level and explicitly watch for EV approaching zero to trigger reallocation.

quotes.topic_title: Resource allocation: diminishing returns and new growth engines
quotes.text: And then when that happens, these are these moments that usually coincide with something fundamental changing. Either people's expectations, externally, market saturation, there's something happening where you need to adjust.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A framework for timing big bets: diminishing returns often align with fundamental shifts (expectations, saturation) that require strategy changes.

quotes.topic_title: Resource allocation: diminishing returns and new growth engines
quotes.text: Then when you land a new thing that creates this new little growth engine and then you put people on it and you optimize it because each change is like 10% win, 20% win, 4% win.
quotes.speaker: Robby Stein
quotes.context: A repeatable loop: find a new growth engine first, then scale optimization where iteration yields large percentage gains.
